context.introduction: Discover the essential ingredients and the concept of umami that define Japanese cuisine. Learn about dashi, miso, and the building blocks of Japanese flavor.

sections.title: Umami: The Fifth Taste
sections.content: Umami is the key flavor in Japanese cuisine, found in ingredients like kombu, katsuobushi, and shiitake mushrooms.

sections.title: Dashi: The Foundation
sections.content: Dashi is a broth made from kombu and katsuobushi, forming the base for many Japanese dishes.

sections.title: Miso: Fermented Soybeans
sections.content: Miso is a fermented paste made from soybeans, used in soups and sauces for deep umami flavor.

sections.title: Seaweed Varieties
sections.content: Seaweed like kombu and nori are essential in Japanese cooking, providing minerals and umami.

sections.title: Tips for Success
listItems: Combine different umami sources for deeper flavor
Never boil kombu, just soak it in warm water
Use short-grain rice for authentic texture
Taste your dashi before using in recipes
